name: LEAN Innovation Sandpit – Fun, Creative & Confidential Sessions (2 November)
html_description:
Get expert innovation support from a team of industry rich advisors specially recruited to solve a business need/opportunity you are facing. The LEAN Innovation Sandpits from the University of Leicester are private online sessions delivered one-to-one with individual companies. All discussions will be covered by confidentiality agreements.

The sandpits are designed to bring your leadership/management team together with University experts (e.g. advanced manufacturing, AI/Data, Space engineering, health, business) industry and innovation professionals to tackle a significant business need/opportunity for your company using action learning techniques. You will benefit, from their combined expertise and experience in a fun, friendly and fast-paced format.

The 1.5 hour, online, LEAN Innovation Sandpit sessions are open to owners, directors and managers of established businesses only. During the sandpit your business directors will join forces with our experts and specialists, using creativity and innovation, to identify new solutions and evaluate which are best to take forward. Our innovation team will work with you, before the sandpit, to identify and describe the business need/opportunity you want to focus on. The sandpit will provide you with new insights and solutions.

The LEAN Innovation Sandpit is open to established businesses that have a minimum turnover of £2m interested in growing their business through research and innovation. The participating companies will have an opportunity to access further expertise through our funded innovation programmes from life sciences to 3D printing and advanced manufacture.

The LEAN Innovation Sandpits will be delivered online by the Leicester Innovation Hub team and are part-funded by European Regional Development Fund. The Leicester Innovation Hub provides innovation and incubation support and facilities to businesses and entrepreneurs to make it easier to access the breadth of research and innovation expertise across the University of Leicester by providing dedicated practical innovation support to help companies reach business objectives. 

The LEAN Innovation Sandpit is open to established businesses that have a minimum turnover of £2m, interested in growing their business through research and innovation in one of the sectors including: Advanced Manufacturing & Engineering; Science, Technology and Environment; Health; Communication, Marketing and Creative Industries; Earth Observation and Space Supply Chains.

Attendees will get expert innovation support from a team of industry rich advisors specially recruited to solve a business challenge they are facing.  

The benefits of the ‘sandpits’ are many and varied. They bring opportunities for knowledge sharing and generating ideas. Perhaps most excitingly the events can identify areas where a business and the University can work together on a business challenge. These sessions have been organised to provide you with a forum to share some of your business needs/opportunities and challenges with some ‘great minds’. The University, in turn, will share their experiences, expertise and industry know-how. During the session, your management team will be encouraged to challenge what has gone before and how to do business by working across traditional boundaries to discover solutions in the world of emerging social, economic and political change. Using their knowledge, skills and contacts, our experts are well placed to help you grow your business through support, research and innovation.   

You can pre-book a free 1.5 hour LEAN Innovation Sandpit to discuss any aspects of your business, to benefit from the combined expertise and experience of around 4 or 5 specialists including academics, industry and innovation professionals.

We will meet with you before the sandpit to identify the business challenge you would like us to address.nnThe Sandpit will work through three high speed stages:

- Play – Use creativity to explore multiple possibilities through using expert minds

- Build – turn possibilities into plans

- Learn – evaluate the plans against key criteria

After the sandpit we will continue working with you to provide you with a funded business innovation project.  

Speakers:

We will recruit a tailored team of 4-5 experts from the University of Leicester and business support community to match your chosen business need/opportunity. The experts will be a combination of innovation professionals and academics/researchers with relevant specialisms.

name: LEAN Innovation Sandpit – Fun, Creative & Confidential Sessions (4 November)

name: How to Embrace Corporate Social Responsibility
html_description:
The acronym CSR can strike fear and/or disinterest into the hearts of many in business, but it doesn’t have to be that way. CSR is becoming increasingly important as a way for businesses to demonstrate they are engaging with wider social issues.  Embracing CSR has several benefits for businesses. These include being able to attract talented employees and raising staff engagement. It also helps with team building because people enjoy getting involved with their local communities as it gives them pride and satisfaction.  It can also boost a businesses profile with positive PR and opportunities to create content for marketing on channels such as social media. CSR can also attract clients as it allows them to see if a company is aligned with their personal values.

They will use a range of real-life examples taken from different sized businesses/organisations whom they’ve has personally worked with. The event is aimed at businesses of all sizes who are looking to develop and improve their Corporate Social Responsibility.

name: Reopen, Recover, Reflect, Reset – Rethinking the Future for Tourism
html_description:
Reopen, Recover, Reflect, Reset – Rethinking the Future for Tourism.  In 2019 the £1.9bn injected into the local economy by 35m visitors supported almost 23,000 jobs. This year, following the worldwide Covid-19 pandemic, Visit Britain forecasts a 49% decrease in domestic tourism expenditure which will impact on the viability of businesses and employment in the sector. There are also predictions that it will take until 2024 for international tourism to recover. Tourism is largely a seasonal business and the pandemic has impacted heavily on the peak months between Easter and October on which many businesses depend. Most UK tourism businesses are also SMEs with around 90% employing less than 25 people. The large number, diversity and small scale of businesses in the tourism industry makes the calculation of the impact of the pandemic on the sector more difficult. One thing is for certain however, businesses will have to adapt, diversify and embrace the new normal if they are to thrive. This event will enable tourism businesses to hear from industry leaders about their experiences and predictions to help rethink a future for local tourism and reset their plans. There will also be an opportunity to hear about initiatives that are being designed to help the visitor economy get back to its pre-Covid baseline.  

This event is aimed at those involved in the management and marketing of local tourism businesses in both the leisure and business tourism sectors. These tourism sectors include sports, art and culture, heritage, indoor and outdoor visitor attractions, food and drink, hotels and other accommodation providers, conference centres, transport providers as well as the public sector and charitable trusts.  

Attendees will gain valuable sector intelligence on emerging tourism trends and insights into future initiatives for the leisure and business tourism sectors to be delivered in Leicester and Leicestershire. name: Bringing the Worlds of Schools and Business Together
html_description:
This event provides an opportunity for schools and businesses to discuss how they can work collaboratively to provide mutual benefit for schools, students and business.  Schools, Colleges and Universities are a key source of fresh talent into organisations. However, the worlds of business and education do not always understand each other and this often leads to wasted, or at least delayed, opportunities for organisations and students. 

This event will highlight some of the benefits of collaborative working, whilst also encouraging shared learning and new partnerships between schools and business.

Benefits for schools and students include increasing readiness for employment and accessing expertise. This could be through bringing potential employers into the classroom to supplement the curriculum and highlight possible career paths to students.

Businesses benefit by helping to bridge the skills gap and by gaining access to a talented and enthusiastic group of individuals keen to access the workplace. By investing time into the partnership, organisations are able to get to know students and develop skills before a more formal interview process, meaning that they are better equipped to select the best upcoming talent.

name: China is Open for Trade - a WeChat Masterclass
html_description:
This online course is designed to give you an introduction to the Chinese digital marketing landscape, particularly WeChat, and to provide the essential skills you’ll need for your success in doing business in China.

  • an overview of Chinese social media / digital landscape
  • a glimpse of Tencent’s world giving an overview of their social media eco-system centred on WeChat and its integration into ordinary lives
  • an overview of Chinese social media users including how they do business and how they use WeChat


This will be a thought-provoking live and interactive discussion on how the Chinese community use the WeChat app and how you can use it when selling into China. You’ll be able to ask experts how to interact with WeChat, learn about their own WeChat business experiences and find out about the advantages this will bring to your business growth.  

The event is aimed towards SMEs who are considering exporting to China but are unsure of how best to enter the ecommerce and social media landscape. 

All SMEs are welcome but our target audience is those who are already have some experience of exporting with a turnover in excess of £500k. B2C companies may gain the most advantage from the course but B2B businesses also welcome.

What will attendees gain? 

A clear understanding of ecommerce in China and how social media is used in a business context to drive transactions. A full understanding of the payment capabilities and the commercial offering of WeChat as well as potential access to 121 support clinics led by WeChat experts (limited availability).

Understanding WeChat and how to use it effectively is essential for undertaking business in China. WeChat is used almost universally in China as a means of communication, a marketplace, a payment platform, media platform, a translation programme, a travel agency and much more. The Chinese do not use e-mail in general and use WeChat for almost all communications.  

Through WeChat’s translation feature anybody in the UK can communicate with anyone in China, irrespective of whether the person in the UK can speak Chinese or not.

name: Responsible and Irresponsible Business: Why it Matters Now More Than Ever
html_description:
As businesses start to look beyond the COVID-19 crisis, this event seeks to identify the areas of risk related to the social responsibility of business. Following the recent publication of the Ernst & Young (EY) Global Integrity Report, EY claimed the pandemic will lead, optimistically, to improved business ethics. Looking deeper into the data, EY found that – actually – only 21 per cent of junior employees appeared to agree, whilst the majority (53 per cent) of junior employees were not confident that their management abides by relevant laws, codes of conduct and industry regulations. In addition, 13 per cent of EY’s respondents were prepared to ignore irresponsible business conduct to boost their own career or pay, with the figure rising to 20 per cent among directors. These discrepancies, we will discuss, are likely subtle signals of more dangerous problems lurking which may jeopardise the performance, and even survival of firms in a post-pandemic world. But is social, environmental and economic uncertainty really the new normal? Or did the crisis ‘wake up’ stakeholders to the issues underlying the business reality?

This webinar is aimed at anyone interested in ethical and unethical business practice. Hear from a panel of business and academic leaders on what socially (ir)responsible business is in a post-pandemic world. With emotions running high and risks seemingly lurking around every corner, those people who are interested in the question; “what will the implications of “the new normal” be for socially responsible business practice?” - should find our discussion most stimulating.

Our hope is that by engaging with the discussion on corporate social responsibility and irresponsibility, our participants will gain a better understanding of the risk and opportunities that societal expectations represent to their business, industry or sector - as well as those within their supply chains and beyond. As such, we are hoping for a very lively set of discussions indeed.

name: Slow Innovation and the New Business Model for a Sustainable Recovery
html_description:
In the COVID-19 scenario, we need to develop new approaches to innovation.  Slow Design Driven Innovation provides one avenue for creativity and innovation to join the action to fight climate emergency, to promote concepts of sustainability and sustainable consumption. Our globalised models of production and distribution, coupled with a culture of overconsumption has led to a system that is not sustainable. This system has been responsible for climate change, biodiversity loss, natural resource degradation, ethical issues, poverty, excess waste generation, inefficient energy use, and increased the vulnerability of many developing communities in which these globalised products are manufactured. Measures must be taken to reduce these polluting and unethical practices that negatively impact on environment and society, and to work towards sustainable production and consumption.

Slow design driven innovation is a potential solution to this problem. Slow design aims at reducing the exploitation of natural and human resources, celebrating their value, and increasing the lifespans of products based on quality and local traditions, in addition to outlining a model of alternative responsible consumption which confronts the current paradigm of "more and cheaper is better".

The event involves presentation from academics (University of Leicester’s School of Business), Leicester-based businesses (Fullalove Clothing), the introduction to a toolkit, and the launch of a digital exhibition of artists interpreting these issues.

name: The Impact of Covid-19 on Supply Chains
html_description:

name: The Best of Building Back Better: Crisis Thinking to Policy Change - and What it Means for Leicester Business
html_description:

name: What is Net Zero and How to Get There
html_description:
The UK Government commitment to Net Zero carbon emissions by 2050 will mean that every business will need to reduce their carbon emissions to zero by that date. For most businesses, customer pressure will require them to hit Net Zero well before then. That means electric and/or hydrogen vehicles plus electric and/or hydrogen heating.  The Government will use a combination of grants and carbon taxes to drive implementation of the policy. All large businesses have to report their carbon emissions now, the government will extend carbon reporting to SMEs over the next 5 to 10 years. Once Brexit and Covid are dealt with, this is the next big thing on the business agenda.

This webinar that explain what the Government means by Net Zero Carbon emissions by 2050. It also explains the steps that will be required to achieve Net Zero and the implications for businesses.  The event is aimed at managers of businesses. They should attend in order to understand the implications of the Net Zero policy for their businesses over the medium and long term.

  • what impact this policy will have on their business

name: Health and Wellbeing: Part of Everyone’s Business
html_description:
There is no doubt that issues such as physical inactivity (caused in part by the increasingly sedentary nature of the workplace), a rise in the reported number of chronic health conditions, and the well documented increase in mental health illness and stress is having a negative impact on the productivity of workplaces. These issues impact not only the employee themselves, but the organisation as a whole, with poor employee health causing employers to incur financial losses related to sickness absence, presenteeism, and high staff turnover.

Furthermore, the COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in a drastic change to the working practices of many businesses and organisations. Coronavirus has created uncertainty and worry amongst many, and therefore we believe it’s more important than ever that employees feel supported to look after their health and wellbeing at work. However, it can be difficult to know how best to support employees, when their needs and interests vary so significantly.

This Autumn, Leicester-Shire & Rutland Sport (LRS) will launch the Wellbeing at Work Charter, a local accreditation scheme to recognise the efforts of local workplaces in Leicestershire, Leicester & Rutland to support the health and wellbeing of their employees. To demonstrate your commitment to employee health and wellbeing, regardless of at what level or capacity this may be, LRS are inviting you to make a voluntary Pledge.

We want to be able to showcase the great work that our local workplaces are undertaking to encourage and embed healthy lifestyles amongst our communities and we invite you to hear more about how to get involved and support us to create a culture of healthy workplaces in Leicestershire, Leicester & Rutland.

The event is aimed at business owners, HR professionals, line managers, and anyone with a remit around staff health and wellbeing for workplaces employing more than 20 employees. 

Attendees will gain an understanding of the importance of looking after employee health and wellbeing, particularly in a time where normal working practices have been changed drastically and many employers are facing uncertainty. They will also learn how to effectively implement workplace health interventions, utilising and hear from local employers who are leading the way in developing a positive culture around wellbeing in their workplace. Delegates will have the opportunity to sign the Wellbeing at Work Pledge to demonstrate their commitment to employee wellbeing.

name: How to Align Your Purpose and Strategy
html_description:
